scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Original typescript text of speech delivered in the United States Senate, April 17, 1900, with holograph additions and corrections, and printed insertions. The speech was intended to persuade the Senate to vote against Senate Resolution 53, which proclaimed the Philippine Islands as territory belonging to the United States, and provided that a government be imposed by the United States. Senator Hoar cites examples of the decision of the United States in the case of Cuba, and also instances of the treatment of Afro-American civil rights in that time. He gives an extensive account of the recent history in the Philippines, with emphasis on the role of Emilio Aguinaldo as a leader. There are many quotes about and from Aguinaldo.
Inscribed to E. W. Doherty from Geo. F. Hoar inside front flyleaf.

relatedmaterial.p: Published in the Congressional Record of the 56th U.S. Congress, 1st session, v. 33, pt. 5, p. 4278-4307, April 17, 1900.
